title: How donations through BottleDrop can contribute to wildfire relief
description: Oregonians can help support wildfire relief funds by donating containers made through BottleDrop until Oct. 7.
content:
The Oregon Beverage Recycling Cooperative, operator of BottleDrop, is asking Oregonians to help support its Emergency Fund to aid with wildfire relief through container donations by donating their BottleDrop account funds.

The cooperative's emergency fund will match up to $20,000 through BottleDrop until Oct. 7.

Oregonians can donate their BottleDrop account funds to the American Red Cross Cascades Region, United Way of the Columbia Gorge and the Oregon chapter of the Wildland Firefighter Foundation.

To donate, go online bottledrop.com/wildfire and donate at this link. Oregonians also can donate their OR-10 cent redeemable cans and bottles by taking them to one of the 27 BottleDrop Redemption Centers and letting staff know they want to donate to support wildfire relief efforts.

“BottleDrop customers are incredibly generous and rise to the occasion to help their neighbors during times of urgent need, which is why we are activating our OBRC Emergency Fund to match donations from customers made through BottleDrop,” said Devon Morales, vice president of external affairs for OBRC.

The Emergency Fund started in 2020, and is used to help raise money for communities during times of need such as wildfire and flood relief funding, warming and cooling shelter funding and humanitarian relief to Ukrainians through Mercy Corps.

Mariah Johnston is an outdoors journalism intern at the Statesman Journal. Reach her at mjohnston@gannett.com.

This article originally appeared on Salem Statesman Journal: Donations through BottleDrop will support wildfire relief funds

Support Wildfire Relief with BottleDrop
Donate NowOregon Wildfires
Last year, Oregon experienced a record-breaking wildfire season with 1.9 million acres burned. According to experts, the Pacific Northwest is anticipated to be at elevated risk of significant fires from August to October. Earlier this summer, Governor Tina Kotek declared a State of Emergency due to the imminent threat of wildfires.
As in previous years, OBRC and BottleDrop are working with boots-on-the-ground wildland firefighting camps to facilitate their beverage container redemptions during this wildfire season. OBRC is also activating its emergency fund, which allows OBRC and its customers to magnify their support for those impacted by recent, ongoing and future wildfires.
Donate Through BottleDrop
OBRC is inviting its BottleDrop community to support wildfire relief through container donations. OBRC’s Emergency Fund will match up to $20,000 in total donations made via BottleDrop through Oct. 7, 2025 to support those impacted by this year’s wildfires.
Donations received through OBRC’s Emergency Fund will be split between three organizations providing wildfire relief in Oregon:
- American Red Cross, Cascades Region, supporting residents impacted by wildfires by providing shelters, meals, and emergency supplies.
- United Way of the Columbia Gorge, Rowena Fire Relief Recovery Fund, providing immediate support for those in need of shelter, food, clothes and more while working with local partners to mobilize resources and lead collaborative efforts to rebuild.
- Wildland Firefighter Foundation, Oregon Chapter, supporting those on the frontlines of the wildfires by helping injured firefighters and families of those killed in the line of duty.
How You Can Donate
There are two ways to donate (and have your funds matched!):
- Online from your BottleDrop account and directly to the OBRC Emergency Fund.
- In-person at any full-service BottleDrop Redemption Center (visit the Customer Service Counter with your containers and let staff know you would like to direct your donation to the OBRC Emergency Fund)
BottleDrop customers are incredibly generous, and we are proud to work together to leverage the power of bottles and cans, supporting organizations making a big difference for communities and residents across the state, especially for those impacted by the wildfires.

argos_summary: The Oregon Beverage Recycling Cooperative (OBRC) is matching up to $20,000 in donations made through its BottleDrop program until October 7 to support wildfire relief. Contributions go to the American Red Cross Cascades Region, United Way of the Columbia Gorge, and the Wildland Firefighter Foundation. Oregonians can donate online via bottledrop.com/wildfire or in person at any BottleDrop redemption center by directing their container returns to the emergency fund. The fund, launched in 2020, has previously helped with wildfire, flood, shelter, and humanitarian relief efforts.
